```
./pypiserver/core.py:137: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \.
  "\.win-amd64-py[23]\.\d\..*|\.win32-py[23]\.\d\..*|\.egg)$",
```

items.title: pip install <...> does not download files hence ERROR: Cannot determine archive format is thrown
items.body:
I set up a pypiserver on Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (you should also be able to see it):
http://pypi-server-ubuntu-2.westeurope.cloudapp.azure.com/

 Adding new packages with `twine` does work, you can see the available packages by clicking on the above link.

However, when I try to `pip install` a package, e.g.
```
pip install --trusted-host --index-url http://pypi-server-ubuntu-2.westeurope.cloudapp.azure.com/simple/ hello_world
```

I get the following error message (the same error message on Windows and Ubuntu as well):
```
Collecting http://pypi-server-ubuntu-2.westeurope.cloudapp.azure.com/simple/
  Downloading http://pypi-server-ubuntu-2.westeurope.cloudapp.azure.com/simple/ (343 bytes)
  ERROR: Cannot unpack file C:\Users\arpada\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-unpack-uznot598\simple (downloaded from C:\Users\arpada\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-req-build-4tny0tje, content-type: text/html; charset=UTF-8); cannot detect archive format

ERROR: Cannot determine archive format of C:\Users\arpada\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-req-build-4tny0tje
```
When I run `pip install` with `--no-clean` argument and inspect the created temporary folders I can see that the folders (`C:\Users\arpada\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-req-build-4tny0tje`) are empty. So I assume that is why the `ERROR: Cannot determine archive format` error is thrown.

I can successfully `pip install` the package if I provide a direct link to the wheel file, e.g. this works:
```
pip install http://pypi-server-ubuntu-2.westeurope.cloudapp.azure.com/packages/hello_world-0.0.4-py2.py3-none-any.whl#md5=18ce0df2131c5670b84af5bf5800acf0
```

So it does not seem to be a problem with the packaging. Moreover, I downloaded and added the latest build files of the [`tabulate`](https://pypi.org/project/tabulate/) package from pypi.org for testing. It throws the same error message as `hello_world` above when I try to `pip install` it from my pypi server (http://pypi-server-ubuntu-2.westeurope.cloudapp.azure.com/).

Any thoughts on what could be the problem?

items.title: Consider further clarification about the relationship to PyPI
items.body:
Hi -- (thanks for making this!)

Would you possibly consider language at the start of the README making it even more clear that this project is not related to PyPI / PyPI.org itself, nor is it what PyPI.org runs?

I've unfortunately seen multiple different folks confused by it and had to explain to them that this project is unrelated (I suspect mostly by the name of the package and not knowing much about PyPI). There already is language in the README saying this package is "PyPI compatible", so one may think that shouldn't happen, and yet as I say it unfortunately seems to in a few cases from folks I've seen.

Thoughts obviously welcome, and happy to send a PR if that's something you may be amenable to -- perhaps saying something like "This package is unrelated to PyPI itself. The pypi.org website, used by pip and other packaging tools by default, is maintained by [PyPA](https://github.com/pypa/), and the specific software used to run it is [warehouse](https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/). This package does however implement the same interface used by the official PyPI, and as such is suitable for self-hosting a seperate server of Python packages."

But maybe others will have an even better idea for how to make that as transparently clear as possible.

items.title: docker container's pypi-server command not displaying mounted packages
items.body:
### Setup:

I'm on Mac OSX. My folder structure is:
```
pypi/
  packages/
    docker-run.zsh
    custompackage-0.1.tar.gz
```

`docker-run.zsh` is just one line:
```docker run -p 80:8080 -v ~/pypi/packages:/data/packages pypiserver/pypiserver:latest```

I run the docker container with `source docker-run.zsh`. 

### Problem:

When I open http://localhost:80 I get a response from the server, but it displays "This is a PyPI compatible package index serving 0 packages."

Running `docker exec <container_name> ls packages` displays:
```
docker-run.zsh
custompackage-0.1.tar.gz
```
Which means that they have been successfully mounted (and at the right location) but the server is not displaying them.

Whereas if I run the server on the host (without docker) with `pypi-server -p 80 ~/pypi/packages`, then opening localhost in my browser displays: "This is a PyPI compatible package index serving 1 packages."

Which makes me assume it's an issue with the docker image.

### Appendix:

The output of `docker inspect <container-name>` includes this:
```
"WorkingDir": "/data",
"Entrypoint": [
    "pypi-server",
    "-p",
    "8080"
]
```
and `docker exec <container-name> ps` returns:
```
PID   USER     TIME  COMMAND
1 pypiserv  0:01 {pypi-server} /usr/local/bin/python /usr/local/bin/pypi-server -p 8080 packages
22 pypiserv  0:00 ps
```

So it seems like the command must have run correctly. I'm still new to docker containers, is it possible that the volume containing the packages is somehow mounted **after** the command is run? Is there a way to refresh the `pypi-server` command from within the container so that I can test this?

items.title: remove_pkg action does not remove all instances the package
items.body:
If a package at a certain version has been uploaded in several formats, only one is removed when performing the `remove_pkg` action. Hence when trying to upload the package again for instance, the upload will fail.

For instance, packages could be uploaded in `*.tar.gz` and in `.whl` formats, as in my case:
```
my_package-0.1.0-py3-none-any.whl
my_package-0.1.0.tar.gz
```
The code causing the issue is:
https://github.com/pypiserver/pypiserver/blob/91a5ebd8b11bc0fef42614dcf539b2910239c8af/pypiserver/_app.py#L134-L141
One can see that the `for` loop exits once the first package is found.

Corrective code in line with the writing style could be:
```
        found = []
        for pkg in find_packages(packages()):
            if pkg.pkgname == name and pkg.version == version:
                found.append(pkg)
        if not found :
            raise HTTPError(404, "%s (%s) not found" % (name, version))
        for pkg in find_packages(packages()):
            os.unlink(pkg.fn)
```
I would offer a PR, but don't want to do that without associating a test with it. And I unfortunately won't have the time to ding into the test code to find out how to do it... :disappointed:

items.title: Problem with different hash algos
items.body:
I uploaded my first package to a self-hosted pypiserver.
Then I tried to install it via pip install, and it failed with
```
ERROR: THESE PACKAGES DO NOT MATCH THE HASHES FROM THE REQUIREMENTS FILE
        Expected sha256 1ef075cf79165a57fc0a8c4e11645fcc
             Got        1ef075cf79165a57fc0a8c4e11645fcc585430b8ec5ae5f390308dd5dfcaaacf
```
which makes no sense, as I don't use requirements files.

I debugged pip for an hour and finally found out where the expected hash is coming from:

It stems from the webserver-output in `_app.py` that renders the `pypserver/simple/mypackage` list of files.

I then looked into `pypiserver` source and found the bug:

In `core.py` I have to remove `[:32]` from `_digest_file` and replace `'%s#%s=%.32s'` with `'%s#%s=%s'`.

After that, I can use SHA hashes of any size (including the SHA256 default).

items.title: How are people avoiding name conflicts?
items.body:
My company uses a local instance running pypiserver to host our private projects. This has generally worked great... except this week someone registered a package with the same name as one of ours on PyPi, and their version number is higher, so pip defaults to installing it. 

That's not their fault, of course, but it means we need to implement a better solution. Surely we're not the only ones who have dealt with this. What best practices have worked for people to avoid this?

Perhaps...

1. Choosing names which begin with $ORG_NAME. This would probably solve the problem of random collisions, but doesn't solve the problem  of an attacker uploading a targeted, malicious package. 

2. (1), together with name-squatting the corresponding names on pypi.org. PEP 541 seems to say that such empty projects are invalid will be removed from PyPi, though. 

3. Always run pip with `--index-url=$OUR_REPO"`, and have a cron job which periodically mirrors all dependencies. (It seems like devpi-server supports something like this out of the box?)

4. Maintain a `requirements.txt` and a `requirements-local.txt` for your projects, always install `requirements.txt` first, so that dependencies of your internal dependencies are already installed and you can run `pip install -r requirements-local.txt --index-url=$OUR_REPO` without needing to fetch dependencies from `pypi.org`? 

Or something else?

items.title: What is the easiest way to setup HTTPS with pypi server?
items.body:
I've encountered issues with my personal install of pypiserver not supporting https, and the --trusted-host flag being unsatisfactory as a workaround, so I'm curious what the lowest bar to entry method of enabling HTTPS with pypiserver is, as I see no instructions of any kind in the documentation about how to go about this.

Should a different WSGI server be utilized? If so, how is certificate information provided for these plugins? For example, if I ran pypiserver with cherrypy using this command:
```
pypi-server -p 8080 --server cherrypy ~/packages
``` 
how do I provide my private key/certificate information to the script? Is there a flag I'm not seeing, or a configuration file that needs to be edited?

Or is it the case that there is no out of the box method of handling HTTPS with pypiserver itself, and I need to setup something with Apache or Nginx?

items.title: CRLF injection via new line characters in URI
items.body:
**Summary**
pypiserver doesn't escape new line characters when redirecting users. I'm not too sure if this is only in the default installation, or that if users used a redirect functionality it would additionally be vulnerable.

**Steps to Reproduce**
1. Download pypiserver and host a default installation
2. Open http://pypiserver/%0d%0aSet-Cookie:malicious=1;
3. Observe cookie being set

**Impact**
Create arbitrary HTTP responses, set malicious cookies, potential for XSS depending on implementation (i.e. location header doesn't redirect to a valid host and therefore displays whatever content is available)

items.title: Remove outdated nginx docs, add instructions for proxy_cache
items.body:
### Context Summary

As mentioned in [the documentation](https://pypi.org/project/pypiserver/#serving-thousands-of-packages ) one option to increase performance is to serve packages from behind a static webserver.

The problem is that this requires the directory structure to have the structure conforming to [PEP 503](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0503/) which is not the default behaviour for uploading files.

### Example

Imagine we are serving the following packages directory:

```
packages
    |-- alpha
            |-- alpha-1.0.0.tar.gz
    |-- bravo
            |-- bravo-1.0.0.tar.gz
    |-- charlie-1.0.0.tar.gz
```

Pypiserver is running with ´pypi-server -P .htaccess -p 8080 /path/to/packages´

Nginx is configured to serve this with autoindex:

```
# server listening on 8080
location /packages {
    alias /path/to/packages;
    autoindex on;
}
```

Installing works for all 3 packages when using `localhost:8080/simple` (pypiserver) but will fail for the `charlie` package when using `localhost:8080/packages` (nginx)

The problem arises from the fact that uploading to pypiserver places files in the package root instead of into an appopriate subdirectory. This causes autoindex to not properly generate the correct structure with regards to PEP 503.

So `twine upload --repository-url http://localhost:8080 --skip-existing dist/delta-1.0.0.tar.gz` will place it in `packages/delta-1.0.0.tar.gz` instead of `packages/delta/delta-1.0.0.tar`.

---

Am I doing something wrong with my nginx configuration? Perhaps I'm missing some option in pypiserver? For now I've resorted to automatically moving them into subfolders in intervals but that's not a very clean solution.

---

Related issue #34

items.title: Tests break with twine 1.12 and above
items.body:
Twine's API has changed in 1.12.0, which breaks our test suite.

This has happened before, and I think the solution is to shell out to a subprocess calling twine's CLI interface, which has a stabler interface contract than the internal API.

Discovered while testing #225, in which PR I also pinned twine below 1.12 for tests. When resolved, the pin should be removed.

items.title: A docker compose example that works
items.body:
Guys, I'm in the process of creating a k8s deployment of pypiserver. I just wanted to fix the docker-compose.yml so it's updated to the v3.3 format.

```yaml
---
version: "3.3"

services:
    pypiserver:
        image: pypiserver/pypiserver:latest
        volumes:
            - type: bind
              source: ./data
              target: /data
        command: -P /data/.htaccess -a update,download,list /data/packages
        ports:
            - "80:8080"
volumes:
    data:
```

You just need to create "data" and put a `.htaccess` file there with: `htpasswd -c data/.htaccess <username>`.

items.title: Test upcoming Twine release (1.10.0rc1)?
items.body:
https://test.pypi.org/project/twine/1.10.0rc1/  is a release candidate for Twine 1.10.0 which I'm planning to release early this week. Please see the [changelog](https://twine.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changelog.html) for detailed notes under "Next feature release".

I believe this is how you test it out on its own:  `pip install --upgrade --pre --index-url https://test.pypi.org/simple/ --extra-index-url https://pypi.org/simple twine` 

I would to hear about any problems this new release causes in `pypiserver`. And if there are some simple tests I can run before a new release to check whether a change in `twine` would break core functionality for you, maybe you could mention that on pypa/twine#314.

(By the way, I also work on [Warehouse](https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/), the new codebase for https://pypi.org, and [your list of similar projects in the `README`](https://github.com/pypiserver/pypiserver#similar-projects) has been helpful to me! And I thought you might want to know about pypa/warehouse#3123 since it's about how your project's metadata renders on the new pypi.org.)

Thanks.

items.title: Problem synchronizing index and package while removed
items.body:
Hello, 
We are serving thousands of packages using pypiserver since last past years. But we were suffering from very slow response and intensive CPU usage while serving our requests due to the index being rebuilt often on requests (using --upgrade etc..).
Then we decided to use what the documentation says: installing `pypiserver[cache]`, using nginx cache and even disabling the hash algo checks, and it is incredibly speeding up our `pip install` commands. 10 times faster !

But on the other side we have seen that using twine to push new package did not refresh the index. So basically our files were on the disk, but not shown on the pypiserver, and `pip install` failed claiming that such version did not exist. 
So I dug a bit in the code, in `default_conf()` and I found `cache_control` parameter, which I have set to `20` seconds. It seems to help, like every 20seconds or so the newly packages appear and are able to be served and installed.

The problem is while removing packages, either with curl (using `--form ":action=remove_pkg" ...` or deleting directly from the disk does not make the package disappear from the http UI, and the link goes to a 404 error page. More over, using many processes/threads, does a weird thing, sometimes it will show the link of the missing package and after a refresh (session changed to other process/thread I guess) the package is not there anymore, and its toggling like that on each refresh of the page. Once its there once its not, but the `pip install ` with this package would failed with 404.

I am using pypiserver 1.2.0 and Python 2.7.6. The app() is called by uwsgi as follow:
```
# bb_pypiserver/wsgi.py
wsgi_app = app(
    root=sys.argv[1],
    hash_algo=None,
    redirect_to_fallback=False,
    password_file='/etc/nginx/conf.d/htpasswd',
    fallback_url=False,
    authenticated=['list', 'download', 'update'],
    cache_control=20
)
```
And the uwsgi command
```
uwsgi --need-app --wsgi-file=bb-pypiserver/lib/python2.7/site-packages/bb_pypiserver/wsgi.py \
    --callable=wsgi_app --pyargv=/path_to_packages --socket=127.0.0.1:9084 \
    --master --processes=8 --threads=4 
```

Would you have an idea how to deal with this strange delete behavior?

Thanks.

items.title: End Explicit Support for Python 3.3
items.body:
Python 3.3 has been EoL'ed since September, and more and more major packages are dropping support, making maintenance more difficult. Pytest, for example, [dropped support in version 3.3.0](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/master/CHANGELOG.rst#pytest-330-2017-11-23).

I think that unless there is a really good reason, we should stop explicitly supporting Python 3.3 going forward.

items.title: Dual-mode authenticate appears broken
items.body:
We have a deployment of pypiserver where we want to password protect updates, but want to leave download and list operations public. The docs (e.g. ``$ pypi-server --help``) say:

> For example to password-protect package downloads (in addition to uploads)
> while leaving listings public, give:
> -P foo/htpasswd.txt  -a update,download

I conclude from that statement that we should use "-P foo/htpasswd.txt  -a update". Is this correct? With this config, I would expect to be able to browse to https://localhost:[port]/simple with no authentication but need auth to register/submit packages. However, on the current master, using these settings, trying to browse to this URL, I get a HTTP 401.

I put together a quick test case (below) based on your great test suite to check these assumptions and ran a git bisect between v1.2.0 and master.

```bash
$ git bisect start HEAD v1.2.0 --
$ git bisect run ./script.sh
3d37c009997ec8f199e54524641726fea260906e is the first bad commit
commit 3d37c009997ec8f199e54524641726fea260906e
Author: Kyle Hornberg <kyle.hornberg@gmail.com>
Date:   Fri Apr 29 07:35:46 2016 -0500

    Add matrix auth

:040000 040000 bdddda1c65ca6fad7fafd944467db5d402931477 424a7dd7630432581a3c8f454036598c741f5074 M	pypiserver
```

script.sh:
```bash
#!/bin/bash

py.test -k stuff
```

tests/test_stuff.py
```python
import contextlib
import subprocess
import time
import sys
from urllib.request import urlopen
from textwrap import dedent

import pytest

from .test_server import _build_url, empty_packdir, port, _BUFF_SIZE, _port, \
    SLEEP_AFTER_SRV, Srv, _kill_server, project, package, pypirc_file, chdir, \
    _run_python


def _run_server(packdir, port, authed, other_cli=''):
    pswd_opt_choices = {
        True: "-Ptests/htpasswd.a.a -a update,download,list",
        False: "-P. -a.",
        'partial': "-Ptests/htpasswd.a.a -a update"
    }
    pswd_opts = pswd_opt_choices[authed]
    cmd = "%s -m pypiserver.__main__ -vvv --overwrite -p %s %s %s %s" % (
        sys.executable, port, pswd_opts, other_cli, packdir)
    proc = subprocess.Popen(cmd.split(), bufsize=_BUFF_SIZE)
    time.sleep(SLEEP_AFTER_SRV)
    assert proc.poll() is None

    return Srv(proc, int(port), packdir)


@contextlib.contextmanager
def new_server(packdir, port, authed=False, other_cli=''):
    srv = _run_server(packdir, port,
                      authed=authed, other_cli=other_cli)
    try:
        yield srv
    finally:
        _kill_server(srv)


@pytest.mark.parametrize("pkg_frmt", ['bdist', 'bdist_wheel'])
def test_setuptoolsUpload_partial_authed(empty_packdir, port, project, package,
                                 pkg_frmt, monkeypatch):
    url = _build_url(port)
    with pypirc_file(dedent("""\
            [distutils]
            index-servers: test

            [test]
            repository: %s
            username: a
            password: a
        """ % url)):
        with new_server(empty_packdir, port, authed='partial'):
            with chdir(project.strpath):
                cmd = "setup.py -vvv %s register -r test upload -r test" % pkg_frmt
                for i in range(5):
                    print('++Attempt #%s' % i)
                    assert _run_python(cmd) == 0
            time.sleep(SLEEP_AFTER_SRV)
    assert len(empty_packdir.listdir()) == 1


# Ensure that we can hit the package listing without any authentication
def test_authed_upload_open_download(empty_packdir, port):
    url = _build_url(port) + '/simple'
    with new_server(empty_packdir, port, authed='partial'):
        resp = urlopen(url)
        assert resp.getcode() == 200
```

items.title: Default --fallback-url causing 403 error after change to restrict non HTTPS access to PyPI
items.body:
After the changes made to PyPI which restrict access to only HTTPS (https://mail.python.org/pipermail/distutils-sig/2017-October/031712.html), the default fallback url used by pypiserver does not work anymore as it uses HTTP.

`  --fallback-url FALLBACK_URL
    for packages not found in the local index, this URL will be used to
    redirect to (default: http://pypi.python.org/simple)`

The default for this needs to be changed to https in order to work with the new changes.


**Workaround** is to add `--fallback-url https://pypi.python.org/simple` as an option when starting pypiserver.

items.title: Installing a pypiserver-hosted package from within a requirements.txt file fails, but doing so from the command line works.
items.body:
First I'd like to say that I haven't been able to verify that this is *not* an issue with `pip` itself, so I'm sorry if it's on their end and not yours.

## Summary
Installing a `pypiserver`-hosted package from within a `requirements.txt` file fails, but doing so from the command line works.

## Versions
+ Python 3.5.2, 64-bit
+ Pip 9.0.1
+ pypiserver 1.2.0
+ OS: Windows 10 AU (running WinPython 3.5.2.2)

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Set up a `pypiserver` host and upload a package to it. For this example, we'll use a package called `gdw`
2. Create a clean venv locally and update `pip` to 9.0.1.
3. **Test Case 1:** From command line.
    + `python -m pip install gdw --index-url http://my_pypi.local/pypi`
    + Result: Complains about https, as expected.
    + `python -m pip install gdw --index-url http://my_pypi.local/pypi --trusted-host my_pypi.local`
    + Result: Success!
    + Remove the installed package: `python -m pip uninstall -y gdw`
4. **Test Case 2:** From requirements file.
    + Create a requirements.txt file with a single line: `gdw --index-url http://my_pypi.local/pypi`
    + `python -m pip install -r requirements.txt`
    + Result:
        ```
        Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement gdw (from -r requirements.txt (line 1)) (from versions: )
        No matching distribution found for gdw (from -r requirements.txt (line 1)
        ```
5. **Test Case 2b:** Maybe it doesn't like non-https and Pip is not raising that warning.
    + `python -m pip install -r requirements.txt --trusted-host my_pypi.local`
    + Result: Same thing
6. **Test Case 2c:** Well what if we put `--trusted-host` in the requirements file?
    + Change `requirements.txt` to `gdw --index-url http://my_pypi.local/pypi --trusted-host my_pypi.local`
    + `python -m pip install -r requirements.txt`
    + Result: same as before.

## Comments
According to pypa/pip#3007, it *should* accept `--trusted-host` inside of requirements files. However, comments in [pip#3799](https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/3799#issuecomment-228840598) imply that it doesn't do the same thing as the command line option...

Here's an image of the PyPIServer index, so you can see that it has a version of `gdw` to pull (also the fact that Test Case 1 worked provides this info).
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5386897/23141782/4fff5df6-f76d-11e6-8d0d-09c2147efec8.png)

---

So, any thoughts on what this issue might be? Should I report this to the `pip` maintainers? I haven't been able to reproduce it without using `pypiserver` because I don't know of any other package indexes to use for `--index-url`.

Thanks,

items.title: Multiple Directory Support Broken
items.body:
Somewhere between 1.1.6 and 1.2.0, the multiple directory support broke. I have this config:

```
[composite:main]
use = egg:Paste#urlmap
/pypi/unstable/ = unstable
/pypi/devel/ = devel
/pypi/stable/ = stable
/pypi/production/ = production

[app:unstable]
use = egg:pypiserver#main
root = /var/pypiserver/packages/unstable
password_file = /var/pypiserver/.htpasswd

[app:devel]
use = egg:pypiserver#main
root = /var/pypiserver/packages/devel
password_file = /var/pypiserver/.htpasswd

[app:stable]
use = egg:pypiserver#main
root = /var/pypiserver/packages/stable
password_file = /var/pypiserver/.htpasswd

[app:production]
use = egg:pypiserver#main
root = /var/pypiserver/packages/production
password_file = /var/pypiserver/.htpasswd

[server:main]
use = egg:gunicorn#main
host = 127.0.0.1
port = 8002
workers = 5
accesslog = -
```

Which works fine for 1.1.6-1.1.8, but under 1.2.0, each of the configured package directories show the same list of packages. I didn't narrow down WHICH directory is being served, but it's either the devel or unstable one (first or last in C ordering).

I could not run 1.1.9 and 1.1.10 successfully because of a paste_app_factory error.

items.title: Upload Size is too small for larger repositories
items.body:
Due to the size restrictions within the `MEMFILE_MAX` setting within bottle, larger packages like [numpy](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/numpy/1.12.0b1) and [pandas](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pandas/0.19.1) (or even Django) aren't able to be included as package dependencies when using pypiserver. Is there any chance that either A) This behaviour can change; or B) That you would accept a pull request with a fix for this? As it stands `request` simply inherits directly from `LocalRequest`, so simply importing `LocalRequest`, subclassing it and then allowing the change to happen from an environment variable would be perfect. I've done as much in my own fork, but would rather have this be part of the mainline. 

Relevant changes can be found from [here](https://github.com/johnpneumann/pypiserver/blob/allow_larger_uploads/pypiserver/_app.py#L11) and [here](https://github.com/johnpneumann/pypiserver/blob/allow_larger_uploads/pypiserver/_app.py#L36-L40). I admit that I'm not a huge fan of just dropping request in and calling the `PyPiRequest`, but my thought process was that it was the most minimally invasive way of doing this. 

I can make it a PR, but thought I'd add an issue before doing so.

items.title: provide systemd service template for pypiserver

milestone.title: M1.2.0
milestone.description:
Plan work for `python > 2.7 & python > 3.3`.

Originally planned: 19-Feb-2016
Released: 24-Jun-2016, 4(!) months later

items.body:
Any daemon is supposed to run as a service, thus pypi-server needs a `systemd` template in order to be used as a proper services on Debian distributions (including Ubuntu).

If nobody has an already made template I will create one and contribute it.

Once this is installed people should be able to contron th pypi-server using commands line

```
service pypi-server start
service pypi-server stop
systemctl enable pypi-server
systemctl disable pypi-server
```

More information about systemd can be found at https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-use-systemctl-to-manage-systemd-services-and-units

HTTP 5xx error codes do mean server side error and they are not appropriate to use when the server rejects upload of a resource because it already exists.

items.title: Provide an easy way to preload some packages that exist on pypi.python.org

milestone.title: M1.2.0
milestone.description:
Plan work for `python > 2.7 & python > 3.3`.

Originally planned: 19-Feb-2016
Released: 24-Jun-2016, 4(!) months later

items.body:
One of the most important advantages of having a private pypiserver is that you decouple yourself from the dependency of pypi.python.org which can go down or receive changes that may impact you.

We need a documented way to do something like:
- upload latest version of package `foobar` from pypi.python.org to our internal server
- upload foobar==1.2.3 from pypi to our internal server
- remove package version from internal server

Please note that fallback feature cannot be used because it does affect all packages. We need to be able to control what and when gets updated.

The workaround at this moment is to manually download these files from pypi and to put them on disk, which is an ugly manual process.

items.title: Package name/version inconsistency with PyPI

milestone.title: M1.1.10
milestone.description:
Originally planned:

  - Move validations from ``main() --> core.configure()``.
  - Privatize ``pypiserver.core --> pypiserver._core``.

Did:

- Speed
- PGP
- version-parsing

items.body:
I have noticed an inconsistency between pypiserver and pypi.python.org with a certain package which is fairly unusual in its naming/versioning. The package in question is python-owasp-zap-v2.4.

The package can be installed from pypi.python.org using `pip install python-owasp-zap-v2.4` resulting in an installed version of 0.0.7. The same fails on a locally deployed pypiserver as the package name appears as python-owasp-zap on this server. 

It looks as though the regex used by pypiserver is spliting (and consuming) the package name on the occurance of -v resulting in python-owasp-zap and a version of 2.4-0.0.7. Not 100% but I think a version in this format is invalid so potentially pypiserver needs a revised regex or some additional logic to check for such cases. Interestingly this worked back in older versions and looks to have been impacted by commit - 2d0de09d306e02086643580c35b94a985ea0f263

I'm open to working on providing such a fix if my above analysis makes sense and seems correct, but before I look into it I wanted to get feedback as I may have interpreted the problem incorrectly here.

items.title: Valid package names are stored incorrectly with new version of bottle

milestone.title: M1.1.10
milestone.description:
Originally planned:

  - Move validations from ``main() --> core.configure()``.
  - Privatize ``pypiserver.core --> pypiserver._core``.

Did:

- Speed
- PGP
- version-parsing

items.body:
Not sure when this was introduced, but pypiserver 1.1.2 didn't have this issue. From the [bottle API docs](http://bottlepy.org/docs/dev/api.html#bottle.FileUpload.filename):

> Name of the file on the client file system, but normalized to ensure file system compatibility. An empty filename is returned as ‘empty’. Only ASCII letters, digits, dashes, underscores and dots are allowed in the final filename. Accents are removed, if possible. Whitespace is replaced by a single dash. Leading or tailing dots or dashes are removed. The filename is limited to 255 characters.

For example, the version `0.0.0+local` is a valid package version, but bottle gets rid of the `+`. I'm sure there are other combinations that also break.

items.title: Undeclared dependency
items.body: The passlib package is required and (if not present) will cause the application to crash when the password_file parameter is passed to app(). Simplest fix is probably just to add this as a dependency when building your distribution.

items.title: support for setup.py register command is broken
items.body:
I have fresh pypiserver 1.1.7 running on current Debian Stable, on Python2.7.

For some reason, running "python setup.py sdist register upload" works, but just "setup.py register" does not (locally):

```
Server response (500): <urlopen error [Errno 104] Connection reset by peer>
```

Or from a remote OSX system:

```
Server response (500): <urlopen error [Errno 32] Broken pipe>
```

... and likewise, using jarn.mkrelease (tool to automate releases) from the OSX system to do uploads fails:
(it does register - sdist - upload in three separate HTTP calls, I guess)

```
running register
Registering z3c.form to http://pypi.vidamin.com:8765
Server response (500): <urlopen error [Errno 32] Broken pipe>
ERROR: register failed
```

In all these cases, the pypiserver log shows just:

```
"POST / HTTP/1.1" 401 713 "-" "Python-urllib/2.7"
```

Which is not very helpful...

pypiserver should accept the register call on its own, even if just to satisfy clients (and users) that try to do "setup.py register" on its own without other commands. My suggestion would be to simply silently accept the call, and do nothing (except log the event perhaps).

Note: I suspect this issue may be behind a few other issue reports about "random" 401 or 500 errors, as well... I thought for a long time I was seeing the same issue.

At the very least, it should be documented that doing just "setup.py register" does not work.

items.title: Add caching for the fallback URL packages
items.body:
1. Add option `--fallback-cache-root` or `-c`
2. If the package is not found locally
   1. Search fallback cache root
   2. If fallback cache root doesn't have the package
      1. Retrieve the package
      2. Store it in the fallback root 
      3. Send it to the requesting client
   3. If fallback cache root does have the package
      1. Check whether package is older than `--cache-control` and if older proceed to 2.ii.a
      2. Otherwise send the cached package to the requesting client

items.title: Copyright dates are outdated
items.body: Harsh Gupta gupta.harsh96@gmail.com points out in email to webmaster@ that the page footer still shows "Copyright © 1990-2014, Python Software Foundation." The easy fix is a change to the templates, but it might be better to simply dynamically substitute the current year for the second date.

items.title: bottle BaseRequest.MAX_PARAMS causes HTTPError: 400 Client Error: Bad Request on packages with more than 100 requirements.
items.body:
Hi. 
Geez, this was a nightmare to track down ;). 
Look at [BaseRequest.MAX_PARAMS](https://github.com/ankostis/pypiserver/blob/0db743cc59b71f36cb138d9849587680d9b020be/pypiserver/bottle.py#L900)

We have a package with 112 requirements at the company, this caused [HTTPError: 400 Client Error: Bad Request](https://github.com/ankostis/pypiserver/blob/000e9779783a8a8c134ca38ca00af4f8803aa936/pypiserver/_app.py#L252) as this exceeded allowed POST parameters.

You can reproduce by building this fake package and uploading it (I used twine):

```
from setuptools import setup
setup(
    name='pyserver_test',
    install_requires=['a==1.0'] * 200,
)
```

```
$ pip wheel .
$ twine upload -r my_locally_run_pypiserver wheelhouse/pyserver_test-0.0.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl 
Uploading distributions to http://127.0.0.1:8080
Uploading pyserver_test-0.0.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl
HTTPError: 400 Client Error: Bad Request
```

Please explain why cap at 100 (I assume this is a question to bottle authors). I can easily fix this in my fork but I don't have an idea how to elegantly fix it for everyone else.

items.title: --log-file not working in 1.1.7
items.body:
I'm confused, or there is a bug.

I'm using --log-file with a pathname and nothing is being written there.

The server is acting as it always has and logs to stdout + stderr instead of to my specified log file.

The process, showing `--log-file /var/log/pypiserver.log` as the place to log.


items.title: Allow Search with Pip

milestone.title: No Action
milestone.description: Questions, dicussions, not-fixed ssues and PRs rejected.

items.body:
This patch hacks the code in order to allow _pip search PKG_. For example: ``` pip search --index http://pypi.intenet.com:8080/search/ MyDjango ``` I wonder if you are interested on this and if this patch is wellcome for your side. 
--- /root/_app.py   2015-03-12 11:16:23.000000000 +0000
+++ /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pypiserver/_app.py   2015-03-12 12:26:29.000000000 +0000
@@ -6,6 +6,7 @@
 import mimetypes
 import logging
 import pkg_resources
+import xml.dom.minidom
 
 try:
     from io import BytesIO
@@ -24,6 +25,48 @@
 log = logging.getLogger('pypiserver.http')
 packages = None
 
+XMLRPC_RESPONSE_SKELETON='''
+
+
+
+
+%(objects)s
+
+
+
+'''
+
+def from_obj_to_xmlrpc(obj_):
+    res = ""
+    if isinstance(obj_,int):
+        res += "%s" % obj_
+        return res
+    elif isinstance(obj_,str):
+        res += "%s" % obj_
+        return res
+    elif isinstance(obj_,dict):
+        res += ""
+        for k,v in obj_.iteritems():
+            member = {}
+            member["name"]=k
+            member["value"]=from_obj_to_xmlrpc(v)
+            res_1 = ""
+            res_1 += "%(name)s"
+            res_1 += "%(value)s"
+            res_1 += ""
+            res += res_1 % member
+        res += ""
+        return res
+    elif isinstance(obj_,list):
+        res += ""
+        for i in obj_:
+            res += "%s" % from_obj_to_xmlrpc(i)
+        res += ""
+        return res
+    else:
+       raise Exception("No valid object")
+
+
 
 class Configuration(object):
     def __init__(self):
@@ -267,8 +310,31 @@
     return redirect(request.fullpath + "/")
 
 
-@app.route("/simple/")
+@app.post('/search')
+@app.post('/search/')
 @auth("list")
+def search():
+    value = ""
+    try:
+        parser = xml.dom.minidom.parse(request.body)
+        member = parser.getElementsByTagName("member")[0]
+        value  = parser.getElementsByTagName("string")[0].childNodes[0].wholeText.strip()
+    except Exception, e:
+        value = ""
+
+    response = []
+    ordering = 0
+    for p in packages():
+        if p.pkgname.count(value) > 0:
+            d = {'_pypi_ordering': ordering, 'version': p.version,
+                 'name': p.pkgname, 'summary': p.fn}
+            response.append(d)
+        ordering += 1
+    res = XMLRPC_RESPONSE_SKELETON \
+        % {"objects":from_obj_to_xmlrpc(response)}
+    return res
+

items.title: Cross Site Scripting Vulnerability

milestone.title: M1.1.7
milestone.description: 1st release under new owners, rescheduled Mon 23-Feb-2015..

items.body:
Versions up to and including 1.1.7 contain a cross site scripting vulnerability.  I acknowledge this is not likely to ever be a problem since the normal usage of the server is from pip rather than a web browser.  I only note it because my server was flagged as vulnerable by a Nessus scan.

The vulnerability can be demonstrated by entering the following in a web browser that does **not** filter XSS (on modern browsers, you'll probably have to disable automatic XSS filtering to see the exploit)
`http://my.pypi-server.com:8080/?<script>alert("Vulnerable!");</script>`

If successful, this should pop up an alert window,

items.title: Does not work in Windows?

milestone.title: No Action
milestone.description: Questions, dicussions, not-fixed ssues and PRs rejected.

items.body:
I've set up pypiserver 1.1.6 on Windows7 using python 2.7.9 and pip 6.0.8.

`http://localhost:8080/simple/` lists my package without problems but
`pip install -i http://localhost:8080/simple pygrids` says:

```
Collecting pygrids
  DEPRECATION: Failed to find 'pygrids' at http://localhost:8080/simple/pygrids/. It is suggested to upgrade your index to support
 normalized names as the name in /simple/{name}.
  Cannot fetch index base URL http://localhost:8080/simple/
  Could not find any downloads that satisfy the requirement pygrids
  No distributions at all found for pygrids
```

The different version of the pygrids package are:

```
pygrids-0.1.tar.gz
pygrids-0.2.tar.gz
pygrids-0.2.1.tar.gz
```

Same setup works on Ubuntu 14.04
